title: US power prices spike as deep freeze hits data-centre corridor
content: Wholesale power prices surged in PJM’s Virginia zone as Winter Storm Fern drove demand above forecasts in a region packed with energy-hungry data centres. Reuters reported real-time prices topping $1,800/MWh in Dominion Energy’s territory, highlighting how extreme weather can rapidly reprice power and gas constraints risk spilling into broader energy markets.
summary: A US cold blast triggered a sharp spike in wholesale power prices, underscoring grid stress and energy-supply sensitivity.
context:
• US electricity demand growth has been accelerated by data-centre build-outs linked to AI and cloud workloads.

• Winter weather can tighten power markets quickly when fuel supply (especially natural gas) and transmission become constrained.

• Grid operators have been focused on winter reliability since recent cold-weather stress events and record demand prints.
happened:
• Reuters said real-time wholesale power prices topped $1,800/MWh in Dominion Energy’s Virginia territory, up from about $200/MWh the prior morning.

• PJM data showed demand around 5% above the original forecast in Dominion’s zone as the storm spread.

• PJM projected a potential winter demand record of 147.2 GW on Tuesday versus the prior record of 143.7 GW (January 2025).
implications:
• Elevated spot power prices can pressure utilities and power retailers if hedges are insufficient.

• Weather-driven price spikes can feed into natural gas demand and basis volatility where pipeline constraints bite.

• The episode reinforces investor focus on grid capex, reliability upgrades, and the cost of serving data-centre load growth.
importance:
• Power is increasingly a tradable macro input for AI-era growth themes and infrastructure bottlenecks.

• Extreme-weather stress tests can shift expectations for utility earnings, regulatory scrutiny, and capacity pricing.

• Volatility in power and gas markets can ripple into inflation sensitivity and broader risk sentiment when disruptions widen.

title: Venezuela sends first direct crude cargo to US under new supply deal
content: A Trafigura-chartered tanker departed Venezuela for Louisiana’s LOOP, the first direct shipment to a US port under a 50-million-barrel supply deal agreed this month between Caracas and Washington, Reuters reported. The move signals a shift in sanctioned-oil flows and could affect heavy-sour crude availability and regional refinery economics.
summary: A first direct Venezuela-to-US crude cargo under a new deal highlights changing sanctioned supply routes and heavy crude dynamics.
context:
• US refinery demand for heavy crude makes Venezuelan grades strategically relevant for Gulf Coast runs.

• Sanctions/licensing decisions can quickly redirect barrels and reshape crude differentials and freight patterns.

• Venezuela has been drawing down accumulated storage as exports restart under new permissions.
happened:
• Reuters reported the Liberia-flagged Gloria Maris left Venezuela’s Jose port carrying about 1 million barrels of Merey heavy crude bound for Louisiana’s LOOP.

• Vitol and Trafigura received the first US licences to load and export Venezuelan oil as part of the deal, Reuters said.

• Reuters cited shipping data showing 10–11 million barrels shipped so far under the arrangement and noted preparations to begin exporting fuel oil as well.
implications:
• More direct flows to the US could tighten or loosen heavy crude spreads depending on volumes and competing sources.

• Shifts in freight routes (Caribbean storage versus direct delivery) can change tanker demand and time spreads.

• The sustainability of these flows hinges on policy stability and operational constraints, including storage drawdowns and production decisions.
importance:
• Heavy crude supply is a key driver of Gulf Coast refinery margins and product crack spreads.

• Policy-driven supply changes can move crude benchmarks, differentials, and energy equities.

• The story matters for traders positioned in heavy-sour grades, refined products, and energy shipping.

title: Saudi equities climb as market prepares to open to all foreign investors
content: Saudi Arabia’s benchmark index rose as investors positioned for fourth-quarter earnings and ahead of a February 1 rule change opening the market to all categories of foreign investors, Reuters reported. The prospect of broader access could lift inflow expectations and affect regional EM equity allocations.
summary: Saudi stocks gained on earnings optimism and anticipation of a wider foreign-investor opening from 1 February.
context:
• Regulatory liberalisation is a key catalyst for EM equity inflows and benchmark inclusion dynamics.

• Gulf equity performance often co-moves with oil, bank earnings expectations, and geopolitical risk premia.

• Foreign access changes can alter liquidity, valuation multiples, and sector leadership in domestic markets.
happened:
• Reuters said Saudi’s benchmark index gained 1.2%, led by a 1.8% rise in Al Rajhi Bank.

• Reuters reported the capital market will open to all foreign investors from February 1, easing rules to attract more overseas capital.

• Reuters noted sentiment was also supported by expectations of upcoming earnings and a recent rebound in oil prices.
implications:
• Broader foreign participation could increase turnover and deepen liquidity, potentially lowering the local risk premium.

• Portfolio reallocations may favour large-cap banks and liquid names likely to attract international flows.

• Regional markets may see relative-valuation repricing as investors compare access, governance and earnings momentum.
importance:
• Market-access reforms can be a structural driver of sustained inflows rather than a one-off trading catalyst.

• Saudi equities are a major EM allocation point, so rule changes can influence regional benchmarks and passive flows.

• The story links oil, banks, and geopolitics—three of the biggest drivers of Gulf asset pricing.
